thread.title: Toronto FC names Bill Manning as club president
thread.title_full: Toronto FC names Bill Manning as club president | Toronto Star

author: Laura Armstrong
title: Toronto FC names Bill Manning as club president
text:
Toronto FC named two-time MLS Executive of the Year Bill Manning club president Monday.
Manning, 50, will oversee all team and business operations as of Friday, Oct. 16.
The team has established itself as “one of the most important franchises” in the MLS since its inception in 2007, Manning said in a statement following the announcement.
He praised the squad for nearing its first-ever playoff berth, the newly-renovated BMO Field and its strong fan base.
“I look forward to working with Tim Bezbatchenko, Greg Vanney and the TFC staff at this exciting time and I am grateful to Mr. (Larry) Tanenbaum and the MLSE ownership for this opportunity to come to a world-class city, and club, to help make its championship vision a reality.”
Tanenbaum, chairman of the MLSE Board of Directors, said adopting a leader like Manning is all part of the organization's bid to bring the MLS Championships to Toronto.
“Just as we have worked to add star talent on the pitch to help build Toronto FC into a consistent contender in Major League Soccer, today we are thrilled to add an equally as important and impressive executive in Bill Manning to lead the club.”
The Reds have not had a president since Sept. 2013, when the club parted ways with then-president and GM Kevin Payne only nine months after he was brought in to revamp a stagnant squad.
The Massapequa, New York native is a former professional player, having played in the United Soccer League from 1991 to 1995. He also holds a U.S. National 'A' Coaching Licence.
Manning's 22-year career in sports management has included executive positions with the NFL's Philadelphia Eagles, the NBA's Houston Rockets and, most recently, the MLS' Real Salt Lake, where he spent eight seasons before parting ways in August.
During his time in Salt Lake, the club won an MLS Cup and Eastern Conference titles in 2009. Two years later, the team was CONCACAF Champions League runners up. In 2013, the club took the Western Conference title and was runner up in the MLS Cup.
Off the field, Real Salt Lake's season tickets and sponsorship more than tripled within Manning's tenure, according to Monday's statement. Manning was also involved establishing, opening and selling the naming rights to the club's home base, Rio Tinto Stadium.
He is the MLSE's third president, joining Brendan Shanahan of the Toronto Maple Leafs and Masai Ujiri of the Toronto Raptors.
More to come.
